metadata.title: An ONIOM investigation of reaction mechanisms of propylene glycol dehydration over H-ZSM-5 and H-MOR catalysts

https://s3-eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/prod-ucs-content-store-eu-west/content/pii:S1381116912002014/fx1/HIGHRES/image/jpeg/1374cb8488b993f6dcdb819b395d1421/fx1_lrg.jpg fx1 fx1_lrg.jpg jpg 195435 886 1793 IMAGE-HIGH-RES MOLCAA 8450 S1381-1169(12)00201-4 10.1016/j.molcata.2012.06.006 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 Ball atoms on the (a) 52T cluster of H-ZSM-5 and (b) 68T cluster of H-MOR catalysts, respectively modeled as 5T (O3Si–O–SiO2–(OH)–AlO2–O–SiO2–O–SiO3) and 5T (O3Si–O–SiO2–(OH)–AlO2–O–SiO2–O–SiO3) clusters are treated as high level and the rest of the molecule treated as low level in the two-layered ONIOM(B3LYP/6-31+G(d,p):AM1) approach. Fig. 2 The ONIOM(B3LYP/6-31+G(d,p):AM1)-optimized structures of the (a) 52T cluster of H-ZSM-5 and (b) 68T cluster of H-MOR catalysts. Bond distances are in Å. Fig. 3 The ONIOM(B3LYP/6-31+G(d,p):AM1)-optimized structures of H-ZSM-5 catalyst and its interaction configurations in reaction pathway for propylene glycol (PG) conversion to propanone (PNE). Bond distances are in Å. Fig. 4 The ONIOM(B3LYP/6-31+G(d,p):AM1)-optimized structures of H-ZSM-5 catalyst and its interaction configurations in reaction pathway for propylene glycol (PG) conversion to propanal (PNL). Bond distances are in Å. Fig. 5 Potential energy profiles for (a) propylene glycol (PG) conversion to propanone (PNE) and (b) to propanal (PNL) over the H-ZSM-5 catalyst. Fig. 6 The ONIOM(B3LYP/6-31+G(d,p):AM1)-optimized structures of H-MOR catalyst and its interaction configurations in reaction pathway for propylene glycol (PG) conversion to propanone (PNE). Bond distances are in Å. Fig. 7 The ONIOM(B3LYP/6-31+G(d,p):AM1)-optimized structures of H-MOR catalyst and its interaction configurations in reaction pathway for propylene glycol (PG) conversion to propanal (PNL). Bond distances are in Å. Fig. 8 Potential energy profiles for (a) propylene glycol (PG) conversion to propanone (PNE) and (b) to propanal (PNL) over the H-MOR catalyst. An ONIOM investigation of reaction mechanisms of propylene glycol dehydration over H-ZSM-5 and H-MOR catalysts Arunwan Jansen a b Vithaya Ruangpornvisuti a b c ⁎ a Petrochemistry and Polymer Science Program, Faculty of Science, Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok 10330, Thailand b Center for Petroleum, Petrochemicals and Advanced Materials, Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok 10330, Thailand c Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok 10330, Thailand ⁎ Corresponding author at: Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok 10330, Thailand. Tel.: +66 2218 7644; fax: +66 2254 1309. Graphical abstract Highlights ► Propylene glycol conversion over the H-ZSM-5 and H-MOR was studied. ► Two products of propylene glycol conversion were found as propanone and propanal. ► Thermodynamic properties of each reaction steps of catalytic reactions are reported. ► The overall reaction enthalpies of pathways on both catalysts are exothermic process. The reaction mechanisms for dehydration of propylene glycol (1,2-propanediol) to propanone and propanal over the H-ZSM-5 and H-MOR catalysts have been theoretically studied using ONIOM(MO:MO) approach. The H-ZSM-5 and H-MOR catalysts modeled as 52T and 68T clusters were employed in the ONIOM(B3LYP/6-31+G(d):AM1) method. For the reaction either over the H-ZSM-5 or H-MOR catalysts, four steps for the propylene glycol conversion to propanone and three steps for the conversion to propanal were found. Thermodynamic properties, rate and equilibrium constants of these reactions are reported. Keywords H-ZSM-5 and H-MOR zeolites Propylene glycol Propanone and propanal ONIOM 1 Introduction Some alcohols likely adsorbed on H-ZSM-5 catalyst were studied by Gorte and co-worker [1]. Adsorptions of 2-propanol [1] and 2-propen-1-ol [2] on H-ZSM-5 were studied by means of temperature-programmed desorption (TPD), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and transmission infrared spectroscopy. The adsorption of 2-methyl-2-propano1 on H-ZSM-5 characterized by 13C NMR spectroscopy was studied [3]. The adsorption of the four butanol isomers in H-ZSM-5 catalyst was investigated using the periodic density functional theory method [4]. Since propylene glycol (1,2-propanediol) has been numerously synthesized using glycerol hydrogenolysis [5–12], conversion of propylene glycol to other useful chemicals such as propanone (acetone) and propanal (propionaldehyde) using acidic catalysts has become more useful and interesting applications. Propanone has been used as important solvent to make fibers, plastic and drugs and propanal as important chemical intermediate in preparations of final products such as plastics, paints and rubbers. As zeolite catalysts as solid acid catalysts have been widely studied for the dehydration of alcohols [13–16], they have been employed for dehydration of propylene glycol to propanal. Zeolites were widely studied for their acidic properties of Brønsted acid sites [17,18] using several techniques [19–33]. Brønsted and Lewis acid sites in H-ZSM-5 and H-MOR catalysts were studied by means of 1H and 27Al double-quantum magic-angle spinning (DQ-MAS) NMR spectroscopy [34]. Although dehydration of propylene glycol to propanal over zeolite catalysts including H-ZSM-5 and H-MOR catalysts were experimentally investigated, no clear mechanism of these reactions has been reported [35]. To rationalize and get more understanding on the experiments of conversion reaction of ethanol to ethylene, the aim of this work is a theoretical investigation of the reaction mechanisms of dehydration of propylene glycol to propanone and propanal over H-ZSM-5 and H-MOR catalysts. Reactions energies, thermodynamic properties, rate and equilibrium constants of dehydration of propylene glycol to propanone and propanal over the H-ZSM-5 and H-MOR catalysts have been obtained using the ONIOM approach. 2 Computational details Due to the two-layered ONIOM(MO:MO) approach [36,37], ball atoms as 5T (O3Si–O–SiO2–(OH)–AlO2–O–SiO2–O–SiO3) and 5T (O3Si–O–SiO2–(OH)–AlO2–O–SiO2–O–SiO3) clusters on the H-ZSM-5, modeled as 52T (H40Si51(HO)AlO83) cluster and H-MOR modeled 68T (H60Si67(HO)AlO105) cluster as shown in Fig. 1 and all interaction species are treated as high level (B3LYP/6-31+G(d,p) level of theory [38–40]) and the rest of the molecule treated as low level (AM1 level [41]). The structures optimizations for the H-ZSM-5 (52T) and H-MOR (68T) clusters and configurations of their interactions with propylene glycol (1,2-propanediol) reactant, intermediates, propanone, propanal and their corresponding transition states were carried out using ONIOM(B3LYP/6-31+G(d,p):AM1) approach. All calculations were performed using the GAUSSIAN 03 program [42] and their structures were visualized using the MOLEKEL 4.3 program [43]. The zero point vibrational energy (ZPVE) corrections were derived from frequency calculations at the ONIOM(B3LYP/6-31+G(d,p):AM1) level of theory. 2.1 Cluster models for the H-ZSM-5 and H-MOR The structures of 52T (H40Si51(HO)AlO83) and 68T (H60Si67(HO)AlO105) clusters respectively modeled for H-ZSM-5 and H-MOR zeolites were constructed from the idealized infinite ZSM-5 [44] and MOR [45] crystal lattice structures, respectively. The crystal lattice structures of ZSM-5 and MOR respectively cut as 52T and 68T were decorated as following treatment. The dangling bonds of 52T ZSM-5 and 68T MOR clusters were saturated with hydrogen atoms, one silicon atom located at the crystallographic positions T12 and T2 were substituted by one aluminum atom, respectively. The complete clusters for H-ZSM-5 and H-MOR catalysts were obtained by bonding one proton to oxygen atom which bridges between the T12- and T2-aluminum atom of the ZSM-5 and MOR clusters, respectively. The 52T cluster of H-ZSM-5 and 68T cluster of H-MOR catalysts and their clusters modeled as 5T (O3Si–O–SiO2–(OH)–AlO2–O–SiO2–O–SiO3) and 5T (O3Si–O–SiO2–(OH)–AlO2–O–SiO2–O–SiO3) clusters, respectively and definition of high and low levels of theory applied in the two-layered ONIOM(B3LYP/6-31+G(d,p):AM1) approach are shown in Fig. 1. 2.2 Structure optimization and potential energy surface The ONIOM(B3LYP/6-31+G(d,p):AM1)-optimized structures of transition-state for the reaction steps for 1,2-propanediol dehydration to propanone and to propanal over the H-ZSM-5 and H-MOR were located using the reaction coordinate method referred to the synchronous transit-guided quasi-newton (STQN) calculation [46] using GAUSSIAN 03 program [42]. 2.3 Thermodynamic properties and formation constants The standard enthalpy Δ H 298 ∘ and Gibbs free energy change Δ G 298 ∘ of all studied reactions have been derived from the zero-point vibrational energy (ZPVE) [47] computed at the ONIOM(B3LYP/6-31+G(d,p):AM1) level of theory. The rate constants k(T) for reactions of the ethanol conversion to ethylene derived from the transition-state theory were computed from activation energy (Δ ‡ E) using Eq. (1) [47,48]. (1) k ( T ) = κ k B T h Q TS Q REA exp − Δ ‡ E R T where k B is the Boltzmann's constant, h is Plank's constant, T is the absolute temperature, R is the gas constant, and Q TS and Q REA are the partition functions of the transition state and the reactant of reaction step whose values are composted of translational, rotational, and vibrational partition functions. The tunneling coefficient (κ) can be computed with the Wigner method [49–51] as κ =1+(1/24) (hv i/k B T)2 where v i is the imaginary frequency that accounts for the vibration motion along the reaction path. The pre-exponential factor (A) is defined as A =(k B T/h)(Q TS/Q REA). The equilibrium constant K at 298.15K and 1atm is computed using a thermodynamic equation ΔG°=−RT ln K. 3 Results and discussion As the structures of H-ZSM-5 and H-MOR catalysts were respectively modeled as 52T and 68T clusters, the 52T cluster of H-ZSM-5 and 68T cluster of H-MOR structures optimized using ONIOM(B3LYP/6-31+G(d,p):AM1) method were obtained as shown in Fig. 2 ; their Cartesian coordinates are shown in Tables S1 and S2 in Supplementary data. The HO bond length of the H-ZSM-5 are 0.971 for HZ configuration and 0.974Å for ZH configuration of which stretching vibrations are 3792.6 and 3758.9cm−1, respectively. These two vibration frequencies are closed to experiments of which stretching vibration is 3740cm−1 [52]. For the HO bond lengths of the H-MOR are 0.971 for HZ configuration and 0.978Å for ZH configuration of which stretching vibrations are 3778.1 and 3690.6cm−1, respectively. As it was found that either the H-ZSM-5 or the H-MOR, their HZ form is more stable than their ZH by 22.78kcalmol−1, the reaction for ZH to HZ is energetically preferred reaction. 3.1 Conversion of propylene glycol over the H-ZSM-5 The reaction mechanism of propylene glycol over the H-ZSM-5 was found to consist of two reaction paths. The first path is the conversion of propylene glycol to propanone and the second path is conversion to propanal as shown in Figs. 3 and 4 , respectively. The first reaction path and ONIOM(B3LYP/6-31+G(d,p):AM1)-optimized structures of H-ZSM-5 catalyst as HZ and ZH of which acidic proton bonds to oxygen atom bridged between the next two silicon atoms, is shown in Fig. 3. It shows also the structures of interaction configurations with H-ZSM-5 in reaction pathway for propylene glycol conversion to propanone. The second reaction path and the related ONIOM(B3LYP/6-31+G(d,p):AM1)-optimized structures are shown in Fig. 4. Cartesian coordinates for all structures of species adsorbed on the H-ZSM-5 are shown in Table S1, in Supplementary data. Potential energy profiles for propylene glycol conversion to propanone and to propanal over the H-ZSM-5 catalyst are shown in Fig. 5(a) and (b), respectively. The conversion of propylene glycol conversion to propanone is composted of four reaction steps. The first step, propylene glycol adsorbs onto the H-ZSM-5 by pointing hydroxyl oxygen of hydroxyl group at the 1-position carbon atom toward the acid proton of H-ZSM-5 and pointing hydroxyl hydrogen atom of the other hydroxyl group toward oxygen atom of the H-ZSM-5, shown as INT1 in Fig. 3. The second step, the intermediate reactant INT1 affords the intermediate INT2 via transition state TS1. One water molecule was formed and bound to H-ZSM-5 oxygen atom. This step is therefore the dehydration step. The hydrogen-bond length, in INT1 (1.90Å) is longer than that in INT2 (1.34Å) by 0.56Å. This means that [H⋯O] hydrogen-bond in INT2 is stronger than that in INT1 because of the [H⋯O] in INT2 is a single hydrogen bonding with positive charge. The third step, the intermediate reactant INT2 affords the intermediate INT3 via transition state TS2. This step is the proton transfer process in order to retain the H-ZSM-5 as ZH. The last step is the desorption process of water and propanone as final product. The reaction of propylene glycol conversion to propanal comprises three reaction steps. The first step, propylene glycol adsorbs onto the H-ZSM-5 by pointing hydroxyl oxygen of hydroxyl group at the 2-position carbon atom toward the acid proton of H-ZSM-5 and pointing hydroxyl hydrogen atom of the other hydroxyl group toward oxygen atom of the H-ZSM-5, shown as INT1 in Fig. 4. The second step (dehydration step), the intermediate reactant INT1 affords the intermediate INT2 via transition state TS1 and one water molecule was formed and bound to H-ZSM-5 oxygen atom. The hydrogen-bond length, in INT1 (1.90Å) is longer than that in INT2 (1.40Å) by 0.50Å. The last step is the desorption process to afford propanal product. The reaction energies, thermodynamic properties, rate constants and equilibrium constants for conversion reactions of propylene glycol to propanone and propanal over the H-ZSM-5 catalyst are shown in Table 1 . The rate determining step for the propanone pathway is the second step of which rate constant is 1.21×10−12 s−1 and for the propanal pathway is the second step of which rate constant is 4.09×10−12 s−1. The over all equilibrium constants for the propanone and propanal pathways are 1.71×10−2 and 8.53×10−8, respectively. The overall reaction enthalpies of both pathways are exothermic process. 3.2 Conversion of propylene glycol over the H-MOR The reaction mechanism of propylene glycol over the H-MOR was also found to consist of two reaction paths. One is the conversion of propylene glycol to propanone and the other is conversion to propanal as shown in Figs. 6 and 7 , respectively. The first reaction path and ONIOM(B3LYP/6-31+G(d,p):AM1)-optimized structures of H-MOR catalyst as HZ and ZH is shown in Fig. 6. It shows also the structures of interaction configurations with H-MOR in reaction pathway for propylene glycol conversion to propanone. The second reaction path and the related ONIOM(B3LYP/6-31+G(d,p):AM1)-optimized structures are shown in Fig. 7. Cartesian coordinates for all structures of species adsorbed on the H-MOR are shown in Table S2, in Supplementary data. Potential energy profiles for propylene glycol conversion to propanone and to propanal over the H-MOR catalyst are shown in Fig. 8(a) and (b), respectively. The conversion of propylene glycol conversion to propanone is also composted of four reaction steps. The first step, propylene glycol adsorbs onto the H-MOR by pointing hydroxyl oxygen of hydroxyl group at the 1-position carbon atom toward the acid proton of H-MOR and pointing hydroxyl hydrogen atom of the other hydroxyl group toward oxygen atom of the H-MOR, shown as INT1 in Fig. 6. The second step, the intermediate reactant INT1 affords the intermediate INT2 via transition state TS1. One water molecule was formed and bound to H-MOR oxygen atom. This step is the dehydration step. The hydrogen-bond length, in INT1 (2.04Å) is longer than that in INT2 (1.51Å) by 0.53Å. This means that [H⋯O] hydrogen-bond in INT2 is stronger than that in INT1 because of the [H⋯O] in INT2 is a single hydrogen bonding with positive charge. The third step, the intermediate reactant INT2 affords the intermediate INT3 via transition state TS2. This step is the proton transfer process in order to retain the H-MOR as ZH. The last step is the desorption process of water and propanone as final product. The conversion of propylene glycol conversion to propanal comprises three reaction steps. The first step, propylene glycol adsorbs onto the H-MOR by pointing hydroxyl oxygen of hydroxyl group at the 2-position carbon atom toward the acid proton of H-MOR and pointing hydroxyl hydrogen atom of the other hydroxyl group toward oxygen atom of the H-MOR, shown as INT1 in Fig. 7. The second step, the intermediate reactant INT1 affords the intermediate INT2 via transition state TS1 and one water molecule was formed and bound to H-MOR oxygen atom. The hydrogen-bond length, in INT1 (2.00Å) is longer than that in INT2 (1.48Å) by 0.52Å. The last step is the desorption process to afford propanal product. Table 2 shows that rate constants for the rate determining steps for the propanone and propanal pathway are 5.78×10−16 and 4.18×10−12 s−1, respectively. The over all equilibrium constants for the propanone and propanal pathways are 1.70×10−4 and 4.10×10−8, respectively. The overall reaction enthalpies of both pathways are exothermic process. 4 Conclusions The reaction mechanisms of propylene glycol over H-ZSM-5 and H-MOR catalysts were studied using ONIOM(B3LYP/6-31+G(d,p):AM1) method. The H-ZSM-5 and H-MOR structures were modeled as 52T and 68T clusters, respectively. It was found that the dehydration reactions of propylene glycol either over the H-ZSM-5 or H-MOR consist of two pathways. The first pathway is the conversion of propylene glycol to propanone and the second one is the conversion to propanal. The conversion reactions of propylene glycol to propanone and propanal over the H-ZSM-5 catalyst, the rate determining step for the propanone pathway is the second step of which rate constant is 1.21×10−12 s−1 and for the propanal pathway is the second step of which rate constant is 4.09×10−12 s−1. The over all equilibrium constants for the propanone and propanal pathways are 1.71×10−2 and 8.53×10−8, respectively. The overall reaction enthalpies of both pathways are exothermic process. For, the conversion reactions of propylene glycol to propanone and propanal over the H-MOR catalyst, the rate determining step for the propanone and propanal pathways are 5.78×10−16 and 4.18×10−12 s−1, respectively. The over all equilibrium constants for the propanone and propanal pathways are 1.70×10−4 and 4.10×10−8, respectively. The overall reaction enthalpies of both pathways are exothermic process. coredata.dc:description: The reaction mechanisms for dehydration of propylene glycol (1,2-propanediol) to propanone and propanal over the H-ZSM-5 and H-MOR catalysts have been theoretically studied using ONIOM(MO:MO) approach. The H-ZSM-5 and H-MOR catalysts modeled as 52T and 68T clusters were employed in the ONIOM(B3LYP/6-31+G(d):AM1) method. For the reaction either over the H-ZSM-5 or H-MOR catalysts, four steps for the propylene glycol conversion to propanone and three steps for the conversion to propanal were found. Thermodynamic properties, rate and equilibrium constants of these reactions are reported.
coredata.dc:title: An ONIOM investigation of reaction mechanisms of propylene glycol dehydration over H-ZSM-5 and H-MOR catalysts
